Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing Research, Training, and Synthesis in Sedimentary Record Analyses: TMI Phase Two (Tool for Microscopic Identification)
Award.AbstractNarration:
1226265
Myrbo

This EAR Geoinformatics Program grant supports a two year project to augment development of a prototype informatics tool aimed at assisting non experts in identifying sedimentary minerals and organic components in smear slides to support paleorecords research on marine and lacustrine cores. Development of the prototype TMI (Tool for Microscopic Identification) has a resulted in an online application. Support from this grant will allow for augmented capabilities of TMI to include: 1) a workflow tool for electronic data capture of smear slide analysis during core description; and 2) a discovery and display tool for data stored in relevant databases. The design will involve a modular, reusable architecture capable of interacting with multiple external data sources (e.g., Neotoma) and workflow tools. TMI will collect and maintain a database of images and data in interpretive modules that will assist researchers and students without professional level experience in optical petrography to quickly identify sediment components in smear slides and to interpret the assemblages to place them in the context of litho- and bio-facies and their environmental and paleoenvironmental significance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
TMI, or Tool for Microscopic Identification, is an NSF-funded resource for scientists and educators focused on the particles that make up the mud at the bottoms of lakes, wetlands, rivers, and oceans.  These particles come from the lake surroundings and within the lake itself:  erosion washes in material from the surrounding soil and vegetation, organisms live and die in the lake, and minerals can actually form in the lake water, depending on its chemistry.  Even some contaminants can end up in lake mud.  Together, these particles can tell us a tremendous amount about what was happening to the environment in and around the lake in the recent or distant past.

When scientists, environmental agencies, or lake managers take core samples from the bottom of a lake, they look at the color, texture, layering, and composition of the mud from the bottom of the core (older) to the top (more recent) in order to construct a chronological history of that water body.  The same thing is done by marine scientists in the oceans.

People with a very wide range of backgrounds want to use lake and ocean sediments to understand the past, and often they don't have the knowledge or training to interpret all of the different components of the lake sediment.  For instance, an ecologist might know every grain of pollen and type of algae, but have no idea about the significance of the minerals in the core. On the other hand, a geologist may know every detail of how minerals form, and how they get moved around the landscape, but not be able to identify the fossils of fish and zooplankton in the core.  The purpose of TMI is to help all researchers expand their knowledge with easy to use visual identifications that don't require special knowledge.

The TMI website has been visited over 100,000 times, and is used in countries all over the world, with the US making up about 45% of the use.  It's used in classrooms as well as by researchers.  In addition to the catalog of images and information, there are guides for identification, tutorials, and images of core samples to educate researchers not only on the microscopic but on the features of a core that can be seen with the naked eye.

All of the particles contained in mud are interesting, and many of them are beautiful as well.  Even students who don't consider themselves scientists often enjoy using the microscope to investigate the particles that make up lake sediment, because of the rich variety of shapes, textures, colors, and features - and the fact that these materials have so much meaning in our understanding of the lives of the lakes and oceans that we rely on and love.

Visit TMI at http://tmi.laccore.umn.edu.
